draw:text-box.text:p: presented by...
Agenda
from C to binary

text:p.text:span: so, we create a simple program in a language, such as C.
Here, in Visual Studio, Microsoft standard development environment.
this program shows a simple message box on screen, then terminates.
an executable is generated, and indeed does what we expected.

draw:text-box.text:p: inside the binary
what the Visual Studio compiler did from our C code is actually generate sequences of assembly code instruction (we call them 'opcode') that will generate the wanted actions.
it's indeed our code
Here, you can see calls to MessageBox, then ExitProcess (the names are self-explaining), with the parameters above.
these opcodes are stored in hexadecimal directly in the binary, as visible on the left.
This is what is actually in the file on the hard disk (the 'hex').
If you'd accidentally open the file in, say notepad - it doesn't really make sense, but at least you have that on your machine - you could find it here (remember, it's hex).
Note that it's actually a very tiny part of the whole file (<30bytes out of 56000).
So let's go back to the opcodes.
hex <=> assembly
now you know that this is what is in the file itself.
this is how it's read by 'us' (reverse engineers, malware analysts, exploit developers...).
the CPU itself only reads the hex.
as you can see, there is a relation:
68 - in hex - is used to push offsets
calls starts with FF 15...
and you can see the used addresses here (read them backward).
so, you see the first byte determine the actual opcode.
and depending on each opcode, the length is variable.
Assembly

text:list-item.text:p: the only information in a binary
CPU reads the hex data itself
no text in the final binary

draw:text-box.text:p: so, the compiler translates our C to a serie of assembly opcodes, which is itself encoded in hex.

the resulting executable only contains this Hex. this hex is directly understood and executed by the CPU. If no error happens, what is here directly affects the behavior of the program, there is no 'man in the middle' from the OS.
so our C code will just eventually lead the CPU to read and execute
if, by any chance, there is some hex that we are not aware, or doesn't do what we expect, the CPU doesn't care.
Color captcha
let's take a break, and have a small color quizz. You can imagine this as a captcha: how would it enable us to identify if we're a robot or a human...
this is green... or at least, if you're not color blind...
but in any cases, if you can't distinguish the color, you can't guess it.
ok, this is green again. but even if I turn this color in black and white, you might guess it's originally green.
ok, this is green, right ? you can either see it here, and guess it (even if the green overlay is broken...)
but wait... anyone Japanese in the audience ?

it turns out that in Japan, even if green traffic lights are physically green, they're described as Blue... I was scolded once for saying that a green light – even though it was ' physically green' is green.
you can't guess these things !
There are some things you just can't guess
Just to say, there are things you just can't guess... like you wouldn't guess that you need to say 'blue' for something 'green' before being told...
That's my purpose here, Intel doesn't tell us everything...
inserting 'something' (updateme)
let's go back to our C example, and use a special C command to blindly insert a D6 byte in our binary...
As you see, Visual Studio (that's 2010 ultimate btw, something that costs around 4000 USD) can't tell us anything about it...
Just a nice pair of question marks...
and indeed, if we check Intel official documentation, there is nothing to see here...
but...the CPU doesn't care

text:p.text:span: but the CPU doesn't care about what YOU (or VS) know, and it just executes that mysterious D6 just fine (apparently)

it doesn't look like a big problem, but if like Microsoft, you base your judgment on Intel's documentation, you just don't know what happens next. No automated analysis, proactive detection, etc... and you need to understand that undocumented opcode.
you don't know if it will jump, do nothing, trigger an exception...
and because of variable instruction length, you can't even tell what would be the next instruction, so you can't guess easily backward from the next instruction.

draw:text-box.text:p: Intel: 'don't do what I say...'
But the funny thing is, if you ask Intel public disassembler, XED, it recognize this undocumented opcode just fine.
Do what I do, not what I say...
Let's get more technical now...
